frame.name: Ranked_expectation
frame.definition:
<def-root>An <fen>Entity</fen> is rated as unexpected for its context in terms of its magnitude. Either some different type of <fen>Entity</fen> with a different scope would be expected, or a different amount of the <fen>Entity</fen>.
<ex>The <t>entire</t> <fex name="ent">apple</fex> was riddled with worms .</ex> <ex>The inevitable fate of the Warsaw Resistance fighters was not finally sealed until nine <t>whole</t> <fex name="ent">weeks</fex> of vicious fighting had taken a terrible toll on the people .</ex>
<ex>A <t>mere</t> <fex name="ent">two percent</fex> of Afghan women are registered to vote.</ex> <ex>The crime scene doesn't wrap up in an hour, never mind an <t>entire</t> <fex name="ent">investigation</fex> . </ex> <ex>It 's a huge engineering project when you 're building a <t>whole</t> <fex name="ent">car</fex> .</ex> Although there are some words that overlap between this frame and Completeness, the words in this frame indicate specifically that the magnitude of the <fen>Entity</fen> is different from what is expected, rather than grading an entity as to whether all its parts are present. The Ranked_expectation uses must occur with an explicit or implicit quantification. The Completeness uses can only occur with entities that have salient necessary parts and structure.</def-root>

FE.name: Entity
FE.definition:
<def-root>The item which is described in terms of its expectedness in the context.
<ex>The <t>entire</t> <fex name="ent">day</fex> was spent on the project .</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: entire.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: with no part left out; whole

lexUnit.name: whole.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: emphasizing a large extent or number

lexUnit.name: mere.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: that is solely, or no more or better than, what is specified.
